Literature Review: Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) has emerged as a crucial player in innate immune signaling, with its release from mitochondria triggering various inflammatory responses. This literature review explores the mechanisms of mtDNA release, its role in activating innate immune pathways, and its implications in human diseases, infections, and aging.The endosymbiotic theory posits that mitochondria originated from ancient bacterial endosymbionts, with most of their genetic material transferred to the nuclear genome over time. The remaining mtDNA, a circular molecule of approximately 16 kb in mammals, has been found to possess the ability to escape mitochondria and integrate into the nuclear genome. This phenomenon was first observed in budding yeast, along with the identification of genes regulating this process (Timmis et al., 2004).Several mechanisms facilitate the release of mtDNA into the cytoplasm. One such mechanism involves inducible mitochondrial pores, including the mitochondrial permeability transition pore (mPTP) and the Bax/Bak pore. The opening of these pores can lead to the release of mtDNA into the cytoplasm, triggering innate immune responses (West et al., 2015). Additionally, defective mitophagy or autophagy can result in the accumulation of damaged mitochondria, increasing the likelihood of mtDNA release (Nakahira et al., 2011).Once released into the cytoplasm, mtDNA activates various innate immune signaling pathways through specific nucleic acid sensors and inflammasomes. One key sensor is cyclic GMP-AMP synthase (cGAS), which recognizes cytosolic double-stranded DNA, including mtDNA. Upon binding to mtDNA, cGAS catalyzes the production of cyclic GMP-AMP (cGAMP), which in turn activates the stimulator of interferon genes (STING) pathway, leading to the production of type I interferons and other pro-inflammatory cytokines (Sun et al., 2013).Another important pathway activated by cytosolic mtDNA is the NLRP3 inflammasome. The NLRP3 inflammasome is a multiprotein complex that, when activated, leads to the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines such as IL-1Î² and IL-18. Studies have shown that mtDNA can directly activate the NLRP3 inflammasome, contributing to the inflammatory response (Shimada et al., 2012).In addition to intracellular signaling, extracellular mtDNA release has been implicated in promoting systemic inflammation. Circulating cell-free mtDNA has been detected in various pathological conditions and can act as a damage-associated molecular pattern (DAMP), activating immune cells through pattern recognition receptors such as Toll-like receptor 9 (TLR9) (Zhang et al., 2010).The role of mtDNA in innate immune signaling has significant implications for human diseases. In sepsis, for example, elevated levels of circulating mtDNA have been associated with disease severity and mortality (Nakahira et al., 2013). Similarly, in trauma patients, increased levels of plasma mtDNA have been correlated with the development of systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) (Zhang et al., 2010).Bacterial and viral infections have also been shown to induce mtDNA release and subsequent immune activation. For instance, certain bacterial toxins can trigger mitochondrial damage and mtDNA release, leading to inflammasome activation and inflammation (Shimada et al., 2012). In viral infections, such as those caused by influenza A virus, mtDNA release has been observed to contribute to the inflammatory response and disease pathogenesis (Ichinohe et al., 2010).The role of mtDNA in senescence and aging has gained increasing attention in recent years. Accumulation of mtDNA damage and subsequent release of mtDNA fragments have been associated with cellular senescence and the senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP) (Wiley et al., 2016). This process may contribute to chronic low-grade inflammation observed in aging, often referred to as 'inflammaging' (Franceschi and Campisi, 2014).Furthermore, mtDNA release has been implicated in neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's disease. Studies have shown that mtDNA can accumulate in the cytosol of neurons in these conditions, potentially contributing to neuroinflammation and disease progression (West et al., 2015).In conclusion, the release of mtDNA and its role in innate immune signaling represent a critical area of research with far-reaching implications for human health and disease. Understanding the mechanisms of mtDNA release, its interactions with innate immune sensors, and its involvement in various pathological conditions may pave the way for novel therapeutic strategies targeting mtDNA-mediated inflammation in a wide range of diseases, infections, and age-related conditions.
